hanzi: 很高兴能见到在中国的家人
pinyin: hěn gāoxìng néng jiàndào zài zhōngguó de jiārén
english: It’s great to see family in China
description: A feeling statement with an attributive phrase. Structure: 很高兴 (hěn gāoxìng = very happy) + 能 (néng = can) + 见到 (jiàndào = see/meet) + 在中国的 (zài Zhōngguó de = located in China, attributive with 的) + 家人 (jiārén = family).

hanzi: 不是，我来过几次了，这是第三次。
pinyin: bù shì, wǒ lái guò jǐ cì le, zhè shì dì sān cì
english: No, this is my third time.
description: A negative answer followed by experience and an ordinal. Parts: 不是 (bú shì = no) + 我来过几次了 (wǒ lái guò jǐ cì le = I have come several times; experiential 过 + 了) + 这是第三次 (zhè shì dì sān cì = this is the third time).

pinyin: jīntiān xiàwǔ nǐ xiǎng zuò shénme?
english: What do you want to do this afternoon?
description: A question about near-future plans. Structure: 今天下午 (time phrase) + 你 (subject) + 想 (want) + 做 (do) + 什么 (what). Shows time-first ordering and “想 + 动词” to ask intentions.

hanzi: 爸爸妈妈做的家常菜非常好吃
pinyin: bàba māma zuò de jiācháng cài fēicháng hǎochī
english: My in-laws' home-cooked food is very tasty
description: An attributive clause with 的. Structure: 爸爸妈妈 (bàba māma = parents) + 做的 (zuò de = made by; verb phrase modifying a noun) + 家常菜 (jiācháng cài = home-style dishes) + 非常好吃 (fēicháng hǎochī = very tasty).

pinyin: nǐ xǐhuān zhōngguó ma?
english: Do you like China?
description: A basic preference question. Structure: 你 (nǐ) + 喜欢 (xǐhuān = like) + 中国 (Zhōngguó = China) + 吗 (ma = yes/no).

hanzi: 我想要一碗大份的桂林米粉。
pinyin: wǒ xiǎng yào yī wǎn dà fèn de Guìlín mǐfěn.
english: I would like a large bowl of Guilin rice noodles.
description: A polite order/request. Structure: 我 (I) + 想要 (would like) + 一碗 (measure word for bowls) + 大份的 (large-portion, adjectival 的) + 桂林米粉 (dish name). Demonstrates measure words, size, and 的-modification.

pinyin: míngtiān nǐ xiǎng zuò shénme?
english: What do you want to do tomorrow?
description: A question about future activity. Structure: 明天 (time) + 你 (subject) + 想 (want) + 做 (do) + 什么 (what). Same “time-first” and “想 + verb” pattern.

pinyin: nàge bēizi duōshao qián?
english: How much is that cup?
description: A price question with demonstrative + classifier. Structure: 那个 (that + 个) + 杯子 (cup) + 多少钱 (how much). Uses 多少钱 for prices.

pinyin: wǒ kěyǐ jiā tāng le ma?
english: Can I add more soup?
description: A polite permission request. Structure: 我 (I) + 可以 (may/can) + 加汤 (add soup) + 了吗 (question with change-of-state 了 + 吗). Softens the ask with 可以.

pinyin: nǐ jiā yǒu jǐ kǒu rén?
english: How many people are in your family?
description: A family-size question using measure word 口. Structure: 你家 (your family) + 有 (have) + 几口 (how many mouths) + 人 (people). 口 is standard for family members.

pinyin: nǐ xué zhōngwén duō jiǔ le?
english: How long have you been learning Chinese?
description: A question about duration of learning. Structure: 你 (nǐ = you) + 学中文 (xué zhōngwén = study Chinese) + 多久 (duōjiǔ = how long) + 了 (le = duration of ongoing action). Asks how long the activity has been continuing.

hanzi: 我刚开始学，学了一两个月了。
pinyin: wǒ gāng kāishǐ xué, xué le yī liǎng gè yuè le
english: I just started. I've been learning 1-2 months.
description: A statement about study duration. Structure: 我 (wǒ = I) + 刚开始 (gāng kāishǐ = just started) + 学 (xué = to study), then clause: 学了 (xué le = have studied) + 一两个月 (yī liǎng gè yuè = one or two months) + 了 (le = experiential/aspect marker). Conveys that the action has been ongoing for about 1–2 months.

hanzi: 會一點兒, 我的中文不太好, 不過, 我正在學
pinyin: Huì yì diǎr, wǒ de zhōngwén bù tài hǎo, búguò, wǒ zhèng zài xué.
english: A little bit; my Chinese is not very good, but I’m learning.
description: A self-assessment with contrast plus ongoing action. Clauses: 會一點兒 (huì yì diǎnr = can a little) + 我的中文不太好 (wǒ de zhōngwén bù tài hǎo = my Chinese isn’t very good), 不過 (búguò = however) + 我正在學 (wǒ zhèngzài xué = I’m studying/learning now). Shows contrast with 不過 and progressive 正在.

hanzi: 你的中文其实很不错；加油！
pinyin: nǐ de zhōngwén qíshí hěn búcuò; jiā yóu!
english: Your Chinese is actually not bad; keep it up!
description: A compliment plus encouragement. Structure: 你的中文 (nǐ de zhōngwén = your Chinese) + 其实 (qíshí = actually) + 很不错 (hěn búcuò = quite good); 加油 (jiā yóu = keep it up/you’ve got this) as a standalone encouraging imperative.

pinyin: kě yǐ qǐng nǐ shuō màn yì diǎr ma
english: Could you speak a little slower please?
description: A polite speed request. Structure: 可以 (kěyǐ = may/can) + 请你 (qǐng nǐ = please you) + 说 (shuō = speak) + 慢一点儿 (màn yìdiǎnr = a bit slower) + 吗 (ma = yes/no question particle). Softens the request with 可以 and 请.

hanzi: 抱歉，我没听懂... 可以请你说慢一点儿吗？
pinyin: bào qiàn, wǒ méi tīng dǒng... kěyǐ qǐng nǐ shuō màn yì diǎn ma?
english:
Sorry, I didn’t understand. Can you speak slower?
[In response to someone speak too fast)
description: Apology + follow-up request. Clause 1: 抱歉 (bàoqiàn = sorry) + 我没听懂 (wǒ méi tīng dǒng = I didn’t understand). Clause 2: 可以请你说慢一点儿吗？(kěyǐ qǐng nǐ shuō màn yìdiǎnr ma? = could you speak a little slower?). Combines acknowledgement with a polite ask.

pinyin: nǐ huì shuō zhōngwén ma
english: Can you speak Chinese?
description: An ability question. Structure: 你 (nǐ = you) + 会/會 (huì = can/know how to) + 说中文 (shuō zhōngwén = speak Chinese) + 吗 (ma = yes/no question). Asks about capability rather than permission.

pinyin: nǐ lái zhōngguó duō jiǔ le?
english: How long have you been in China?
description: A duration question about being in a place. Structure: 你 (nǐ = you) + 来中国 (lái Zhōngguó = come to China) + 多久 (duōjiǔ = how long) + 了 (le = duration/aspect). Asks how long the situation has lasted.

pinyin: wǒ lái zhōngguó jǐ tiān le
english: I’ve been here for several days/weeks.
description: A duration statement. Structure: 我 (wǒ = I) + 来中国 (lái Zhōngguó = came to China) + 几天 (jǐ tiān = several days) + 了 (le = duration marker). States how long you have been in China (here: several days).

pinyin: nǐ dì yī cì lái zhōngguó ma?
english: Is this your first time in China?
description: A first-time yes/no question with an ordinal. Structure: 你 (nǐ) + 第一次 (dì yī cì = first time) + 来中国 (lái Zhōngguó = come to China) + 吗 (ma = yes/no).

hanzi: 我也很喜欢这里的美食
pinyin: wǒ yě hěn xǐhuān zhèlǐ de měishí
english: I also really like the food here
description: A liking statement with “also” and an attributive phrase. Structure: 我也 (wǒ yě = I also) + 很喜欢 (hěn xǐhuān = really like) + 这里的 (zhèlǐ de = here’s, attributive) + 美食 (měishí = cuisine/food).

pinyin: tǐng xǐhuān de
english: Quite like it!
description: Comment sentence using the adverb 挺…的. Pattern: 挺 (tǐng = quite/very) + 喜欢 (xǐhuān = like) + 的 (de = sentence-final particle forming a comment). Subject is understood from context.

pinyin: nǐ xíguàn zhōngguó de shēnghuó ma?
english: Are you used to life in China?
description: A yes/no question about being accustomed. Structure: 你 (nǐ) + 习惯 (xíguàn = be used to) + 中国的生活 (Zhōngguó de shēnghuó = life in China, attributive 的) + 吗 (ma).

hanzi: 还不太习惯，但我在慢慢适应。
pinyin: hái bù tài xíguàn, dàn wǒ zài màn màn shìyìng
english: I’m not used to it yet, but I’m adjusting slowly.
description: Contrast between current state and gradual change. Clause 1: 还不太习惯 (hái bù tài xíguàn = not quite used to yet). Clause 2: 但我在慢慢适应 (dàn wǒ zài mànmàn shìyìng = but I am slowly adapting; 在… indicates ongoing action).

pinyin: nǐ xiǎng hē shénme?
english: What would you like to drink?
description: A drink-preference question. Structure: 你 (you) + 想喝 (want to drink) + 什么 (what). Uses “想 + 喝” to ask preference.

pinyin: nǐ qù nǎge shāngdiàn mǎi bēizi?
english: Which store do you go to buy a cup?
description: An information question with place choice. Structure: 你 (you) + 去 (go) + 哪个商店 (which store) + 买杯子 (to buy a cup). Shows “去 + 地点 + V + 目的”.

pinyin: nǐ yào là de háishì bù là de?
english: Do you want the spicy one or the non-spicy one?
description: A choice question with 还是. Structure: 你要 (you want) + 辣的 / 不辣的 (spicy / not spicy, nominalized with 的) + 还是 (or). Offers A/B options.

pinyin: nǐ yǒu duōshao gè Hànyǔ lǎoshī?
english: How many Chinese teachers do you have?
description: A quantity question with 多少 and 个. Structure: 你 (you) + 有 (have) + 多少个 (how many + classifier) + 汉语老师 (Chinese teachers).

pinyin: nǐ hǎo! zhège bēizi duōshao qián
english: Hello! How much is this cup?
description: Greeting + price question. Structure: 你好！ (hello) + 这个杯子 (this cup) + 多少钱 (how much). Combines salutation with a cost inquiry.

pinyin: wǒ jiā yǒu sān kǒu rén.
english: There are three people in my family.
description: A family-size statement with 口. Structure: 我家 (my family) + 有 (have) + 三口人 (three members). Uses 口 as the family classifier.

pinyin: wǒ xiǎng jiā tāng, xièxie!
english: I would like to add some soup, thank you!
description: A polite request + thanks. Structure: 我想 (I’d like to) + 加汤 (add soup) + ，谢谢 (thank you). Uses 想 for soft request.

pinyin: yí gè bēizi duōshao qián?
english: How much is a cup?
description: A price question with numeral + classifier. Structure: 一个 (one + 个) + 杯子 (cup) + 多少钱 (how much).

pinyin: zhè shì shénme?
english: What is this?
description: A basic identification question. Structure: 这 (this) + 是 (is) + 什么 (what). Uses 是…什么 for “what is this”.

pinyin: zhège bēizi duōshao qián?
english: How much is this cup?
description: A price question with demonstrative. Structure: 这个 (this) + 杯子 (cup) + 多少钱 (how much). Standard shopping phrase.

hanzi: 你们学校有多少个学生？
pinyin: nǐmen xuéxiào yǒu duōshao gè xuéshēng?
english: How many students does your school have?
description: An institutional quantity question. Structure: 你们学校 (your school) + 有 (have) + 多少个 (how many + classifier) + 学生 (students).

pinyin: nǐ shǔ shénme?
english: What is your Chinese zodiac sign?
description: Question about zodiac. Structure: 你 (nǐ = you) + 属 (shǔ = to belong to; used for zodiac animals) + 什么 (shénme = what). Common way to ask someone’s zodiac animal year.

pinyin: zhēn hǎo!
english: Really good! / So nice!
description: Exclamatory sentence. Structure: 真 (zhēn = really/so) + 好 (hǎo = good). Often used to express admiration, praise, or satisfaction.

pinyin: zhēn de?!
english: Really?! / Is that true?!
description: Exclamatory question showing surprise or doubt. Structure: 真 (zhēn = really) + 的 (de, particle for emphasis). Tone varies from curiosity to disbelief depending on context.

pinyin: nǐ tài hǎo le!
english: You are so nice! / That’s great of you!
description: Exclamatory sentence used to praise or thank someone. Structure: 你 (nǐ = you) + 太 (tài = too/so) + 好 (hǎo = good/nice) + 了 (le = intensifier). Commonly used as a strong compliment.

pinyin: hái búcuò.
english: Not bad; pretty good.
description: Mild/soft compliment. Softer than “很好”; used for polite or modest evaluation.

pinyin: yuè lái yuè hǎo le.
english: Getting better and better.
description: Pattern “越来越 + Adj.” shows increasing degree. 了 marks a change of state.

hanzi: 我的中文说得还可以吗？
pinyin: wǒ de Zhōngwén shuō de hái kěyǐ ma?
english: Is my Chinese OK?
description: Polite self-check. Structure: Subj + Obj + Verb + 得 + 程度 (还可以/很好). Uses 吗 for yes/no.

pinyin: yí lù píng’ān!
english: Have a safe trip!
description: Farewell blessing. Structure: 一路 (yílù = the whole journey) + 平安 (píng’ān = safe). Commonly said to travelers: “Safe travels!”

pinyin: zhù nǐ lǚtú yúkuài!
english: Wish you a pleasant journey!
description: Polite farewell phrase. Structure: 祝 (zhù = to wish) + 你 (nǐ = you) + 旅途 (lǚtú = journey) + 愉快 (yúkuài = pleasant/happy).

pinyin: nǐ qù nǎr?
english: Where are you going?
description: Travel question. Structure: 你 (you) + 去 (go) + 哪儿 (where). Colloquial northern form with 儿化.

pinyin: nǐ jǐ diǎn chūfā?
english: What time are you leaving?
description: Departure-time question. 几点 (what time) + 出发 (set off/leave).

pinyin: nǐ jǐ diǎn dàodá?
english: What time do you arrive?
description: Arrival-time question. 几点 (what time) + 到达 (arrive).

pinyin: xūyào wǒ sòng nǐ qù jīchǎng ma?
english: Do you need me to take you to the airport?
description: Offer of help. 需要 (need) + 我送你 (I give you a ride) + 去机场 (to the airport) + 吗 (yes/no).

pinyin: dài hǎo hùzhào le ma?
english: Did you bring your passport?
description: Check/reminder. 带好 (have brought) + 护照 (passport) + 了吗 (new state / completed action).

pinyin: yí lù shùnfēng!
english: Have a smooth trip!
description: Farewell blessing. 一路 (whole journey) + 顺风 (smooth tailwind). Equivalent to “Bon voyage.”

hanzi: 我要辣椒，不过，不要太辣！
pinyin: wǒ yào làjiāo, búguò, bú yào tài là!
english: I want chili, but not too spicy!
description: Ordering/request phrase. Structure: 我要 (I want) + 辣椒 (chili/pepper), 不过 (but), 不要 (don’t want) + 太辣 (too spicy). Common in restaurants to express preference.

pinyin: bú yào là.
english: No spice, please.
description: Clear preference: 不要 (don’t want) + 辣 (spicy). Polite, concise request in restaurants.

pinyin: duō fàng yìdiǎn làjiāo.
english: Add a bit more chili, please.
description: Quantity request: 多放 (add more) + 一点 (a bit) + 辣椒 (chili).

pinyin: shǎo fàng làjiāo.
english: Go easy on the chili.
description: Quantity softener: 少放 (put less) + 辣椒 (chili).

pinyin: néng bù néng zuò wēi là?
english: Could you make it mild?
description: Polite request with 能不能 (could you) + 做 (make) + 微辣 (mild spicy).

pinyin: wǒ qù!
english: Damn! / Whoa! / Oh my god!
description: Colloquial slang exclamation. Literally “I go,” but used as an interjection of surprise, annoyance, or amazement in spoken Chinese. Tone depends on context.

pinyin: chī shénme hái méi xiǎng hǎo.
english: I haven’t decided what to eat yet.
description: Casual statement. Structure: 吃什么 (what to eat) as topic + 还没 (still not yet) + 想好 (decided). Common phrase when discussing meal choices.

pinyin: wǒ tǐng xǐhuān A, dànshì gèng xǐhuān B.
english: I quite like A, but I like B even more.
description: Preference + contrast sentence. Structure: 我挺喜欢… (I quite like …) + 但是 (but) + 更喜欢… (like … even more). Common way to compare choices in spoken Chinese.

hanzi: 不过，我不太喜欢吃猪肉！
pinyin: búguò, wǒ bù tài xǐhuān chī zhūròu!
english: However, I don’t really like eating pork!
description: Contrast statement. Structure: 不过 (búguò = however) + 我 (I) + 不太喜欢 (don’t really like) + 吃猪肉 (to eat pork). Common phrase to state food dislikes politely.

pinyin: wǒ hěn xǐhuān chī niúròu.
english: I really like eating beef.
description: Positive preference. Structure: 我 (I) + 很喜欢 (really like) + 吃牛肉 (to eat beef). A common way to express likes.

pinyin: wǒ zuì xǐhuān chī jīròu.
english: I like eating chicken the most.
description: Superlative preference. Structure: 我 (I) + 最喜欢 (like the most) + 吃鸡肉 (to eat chicken). Useful for expressing favorites.

hanzi: 我想要两个酸菜牛肉油泼面，一个不要香菜，一个打包，不要香菜和葱。
pinyin: wǒ xiǎng yào liǎng gè suān cài niú ròu yóu pō miàn, yī gè bú yào xiāng cài, yī gè dǎ bāo, bú yào xiāng cài hé cōng.
english: I’d like two sour-cabbage beef oil-splashed noodles; one without cilantro, and one to go, without cilantro or scallions.
description: Ordering request with options. Structure: 我想要… (I’d like) + 数量 (两个) + 菜名 (酸菜牛肉油泼面); 子句1：不要X（不要香菜）; 子句2：打包（to-go）; 子句3：不要X和Y（不要香菜和葱）。“不要” negates ingredients; “打包” requests takeout.
